description: Civic engagement context for Fairfax County and Northern Virginia - governance structure, key issues, decision-making bodies, and civic participation framework

local_governance_structure.description: Key decision-making bodies and officials in Fairfax County
content: Fairfax County Board of Supervisors: 9 district supervisors + 1 chairman, meet 1st & 3rd Tuesday monthly
Fairfax County Public Schools (FCPS) Board: 12 members, 193,000+ students, 3rd largest district in Virginia
Planning Commission: Reviews zoning applications, comprehensive plan amendments, holds public hearings
Board of Zoning Appeals: Hears variance requests and special exception cases
School Board meets 2nd & 4th Thursday monthly at Luther Jackson MS
County Executive: serves as chief administrative officer, implements Board policies
9 supervisor districts: Braddock, Dranesville, Hunter Mill, Lee, Mason, Mount Vernon, Providence, Springfield, Sully
At-large Chairman elected countywide
School Board: 9 district reps + 3 at-large members
Virginia House of Delegates: Northern Virginia has ~40 delegates
Virginia Senate: Northern Virginia has ~15 senators
U.S. Congress: Districts 8, 10, 11 cover Fairfax area

key_civic_issues.description: Ongoing civic issues affecting Fairfax County residents
content: School funding: FCPS budget battles, teacher pay, facility needs
Housing affordability: Missing middle housing, zoning reform, development density
Transportation: Metro funding, Route 28/66/495 congestion, bike/ped infrastructure
Development: Rezoning applications, comprehensive plan amendments, neighborhood impacts
Taxes: Real estate assessments, tax rate decisions, budget priorities
Public safety: Police funding, emergency services, mental health response
Environment: Tree canopy preservation, stormwater management, climate action

civic_participation_touchpoints.description: How residents engage with local government
content: Public hearings: BOS, Planning Commission, School Board all have citizen comment periods
Budget process: Feb-Apr, includes town halls and public input sessions
Zoning applications: 15-day neighbor notification, public hearing opportunities
School boundary reviews: When schools are over/under capacity, community engagement process
Comprehensive Plan: Updated every 5 years, extensive public input
Citizen advisory committees: 50+ committees on various topics
Elections: Nov general, June primaries, May local (odd years)

high_priority_signals.description: Signals that indicate important civic developments
content: Board/School Board meeting agendas with action items
Zoning application filings (especially rezonings, not administrative permits)
Proposed ordinance/policy changes
Budget amendments or significant expenditures
Leadership changes (appointments, resignations, retirements)
Public hearing schedules
Election filing deadlines and candidate announcements
Legislative bills affecting local governance (dillon rule, taxation, education)
Development proposals >50 units or >100K sq ft commercial
School capacity studies and boundary changes

regional_context.description: Northern Virginia regional governance and planning
content: Northern Virginia Regional Commission (NVRC): Coordinates across jurisdictions
Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments (MWCOG): Regional planning for DC metro
WMATA: Regional transit authority governing Metro
Virginia Railway Express (VRE): Commuter rail service
Regional housing initiatives: coordinated affordable housing efforts
Transportation planning: I-495/I-66 managed lanes, future projects

state_legislative_impact.description: How Virginia General Assembly affects local governance
content: Dillon Rule state: Localities only have powers explicitly granted by GA
Education funding: State share of K-12 budget, Standards of Quality
Taxation authority: GA controls what taxes localities can levy
Land use: Proffers, zoning authority defined by state code
Elections: State sets election laws, redistricting every 10 years
Transportation funding: NVTA allocates regional gas tax revenue
Key session dates: GA convenes 2nd Wed in January, 60-day session (long years) or 30-day (short years)
